bibl.title: The Impact of Buddhim on Chinese Material Culture

note.p: Chinese monks used to use monks' robes of different colors (often indicating different schools), ranging grey, brown, to black until ca. the tenth cent.; afterwards the color of the robes got gradually standardized; the monks' robe was a powerful symbol for the Buddhist clergy and becoming a monk was often described in terms of changing garment; there is an abundancy of writings concerning the outfit for monks throughout Buddhist history in China....

sense.def: BUDDH: monks' robe; skr. kaṣāya (Chinese monks used to use monks' robes of different colors (often indicating different schools), ranging grey, brown, to black until ca. the tenth cent.; afterwards the color of the robes got gradually standardized; the monks' robe was a powerful symbol for the Buddhist clergy and becoming a monk was often described in terms of changing garment; there is an abundancy of writings concerning the outfit for monks throughout Buddhist history in China)
